sections.title: Who Gets What When You're Gone
sections.subtitle: Properly designating beneficiaries for all your accounts and policies

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Special considerations for different account types

sections.title: Assets with Beneficiary Designations
sections.content: Many financial accounts bypass probate and go directly to named beneficiaries. These include retirement accounts (401(k), IRA), life insurance policies, annuities, and some bank accounts. Proper beneficiary designations ensure these assets go to your intended recipients.

points.title: Primary vs. Contingent
points.description: Name primary beneficiaries first, then contingent beneficiaries as backups.

points.title: Percentage Allocations
points.description: Specify percentage splits for multiple beneficiaries to avoid disputes.

points.title: Regular Updates
points.description: Review and update beneficiaries after marriage, divorce, births, or deaths.

sections.title: Beneficiaries Override Wills
sections.content: Beneficiary designations take precedence over instructions in your will. Keep them current and coordinated with your overall estate plan.

sections.title: Special Considerations
sections.content: For minor children, consider naming a trust as beneficiary rather than the child directly. Update beneficiaries on all accounts annually or after major life events. Consider tax implications for different beneficiary choices.

sections.title: Review Your Beneficiary Designations
steps: List all accounts and policies that have beneficiary designations
Review current beneficiaries for each account
Update any outdated or incorrect designations
Coordinate beneficiary choices with your overall estate plan

sections.title: Keep a Master List
sections.content: Maintain a current list of all your accounts, their beneficiary designations, and where the original documents are stored. Share this with your executor or trusted family member.
